# Perfect XOR | Cryptography

*Can you decrypt the flag?*

```python
import base64

n = 1
i = 0

cipher_b64 = b""

def a(n):
    b = 0
    for i in range(1, n):
        if(n % i == 0):
            b += i
    print(b == n)
    return b == n

# 1) print "flag{"
print("flag{", end='', flush=True)

# 2) decode cipher from base 64 then split on commas (",")
cipher = base64.b64decode(cipher_b64).decode().split(",")
print(cipher)

# 3) for each list item, 
while(i < len(cipher)):
    if (a(n)):
        print(chr(int(cipher[i]) ^ n), end='', flush=True)
        i += 1
    n+=1

print("}")
```

Trying to determine `n`, I managed to print the first 3 numbers, `6 28 496`.  Searching for this number series on Google reveals "Perfect Numbers".  The `cipher` list also contains `14` elements, so we need the first 14 perfect numbers (got it from [here](https://web.archive.org/web/20090503154707/http://amicable.homepage.dk/perfect.htm)):

```python
perfect_numbers = [
    6,
    28,
    496,
    8128,
    33550336,
    8589869056,
    137438691328,
    2305843008139952128,
    2658455991569831744654692615953842176,
    191561942608236107294793378084303638130997321548169216,
    13164036458569648337239753460458722910223472318386943117783728128,
    14474011154664524427946373126085988481573677491474835889066354349131199152128,
    ,
    
]
```

Modifying the original script, we can use these numbers in place of the `a(n)` function to get the flag:

```python
import base64

i = 0

cipher_b64 = b""

perfect_numbers = [
    6,
    28,
    496,
    8128,
    33550336,
    8589869056,
    137438691328,
    2305843008139952128,
    2658455991569831744654692615953842176,
    191561942608236107294793378084303638130997321548169216,
    13164036458569648337239753460458722910223472318386943117783728128,
    14474011154664524427946373126085988481573677491474835889066354349131199152128,
    ,
    
]

# 1) print "flag{"
print("flag{", end='', flush=True)

# 2) decode cipher from base 64 then split on commas (",")
cipher = base64.b64decode(cipher_b64).decode().split(",")

# 3) for each list item, 
while(i < len(cipher)):
    print(chr(int(cipher[i]) ^ perfect_numbers[i]), end='', flush=True)
    i += 1

print("}")
```

The flag is:

```
$ python3 decrypt.py
flag{tHE_br0kEN_Xor}
```
